Very challenging mountain bike trail. Can loop with FS Road 4110 and the Manastash Ridge trail #1388. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Fort Ebby St Park
places.directions: First get onto Whidbey Island either via the ferry, Mukeltio to Clinton or driving around and coming down over Deception Pass bridge. From Clinton take Hwy 525 N to 20 E, a total of about 25 miles. Take a left on Libbey rd and follow the signs to the park. It is well worth stopping by the Park office for a free trail map.

activities.name: Fort Ebey St Park
activities.description:
This area is a literal maze of trails cut through the forest of this park and the adjoining Kettles Park, see pic of map. Although there are no mountains there are many, many small steep hills. Most of the intersections are well signed and the park service has done a great job of keeping downed trees from across the trails. A lot of the trails I rode were very newly blazed and some were barely handlebar width between the trees, a very fun and fast trail system.
The trails in Kettles park near the Hwy connect with a paved trail that runs south to the community of Coupville (4 miles). It may be a little far from Seattle for just a day trip but with beach access, hiking trails, history, picnic areas and about 35 campsites some w/hookups why not make it a weekend trip.

activities.name: Fort Ebby St Park
activities.description: Fort Ebby St Park features 25 miles of hiking trails near Coupville/whidbey Is, WA.

places.name: Hells Crossing
places.directions: From Naches, take Highway 410 approximately 38 miles northwest to milepost 83.4.

activities.name: Hells Crossing
activities.description: Hells Crossing Campground is located along the American River in the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest in Washington&amp;#39;s Cascade Range. Warm summer days and easy access to an abundance of recreational activities make the campground a perfect setting for individual and group camping excursions.

places.name: Olallie State Park
places.directions: Located four miles east of North Bend, Washington, in the I-90 Mountains to Sound Greenway in King County.
places.description: Olallie State Park, a 2,500 acre day-use park on the western slopes of the Cascade Mountains, is a popular location for hiking, picnicking, fishing and rock climbing. The park features dramatic waterfalls, cliff formations and old-growth trees over 10 feet in diameter. The park's most popular destinations are Twin Falls, Weeks Falls, Cedar Butte and Mount Washington.

activities.name: Olallie State Park
activities.description: Beautiful hiking in the Cascadia Mountain Range.

places.name: Chatter Creek Group Site
places.directions: From Seattle take Highway 2 East through Monroe and then over Stevens&apos;Pass.  Take a right on Icicle River Road and follow road approximately 16miles.  The campground will be on the right.  From the East take Highway 2 West through Leavenworth.   Take a left onIcicle River Road and follow road approximately 16 miles.  The campgroundwill be on the right.  From the South take Highway 97 North to Highway 2.  Take Highway 2West through Leavenworth.  Take a left on Icicle River Road and followroad approximately 16 miles.  The campground will be on the right.

activities.name: Chatter Creek Group Site
activities.description: Beneath a canopy of pine and fir on the banks of Chatter Creek, this campground offers a serene setting for groups and large gatherings.

places.name: Louie Trail #1126
places.directions: TBD

activities.name: Louie Trail #1126
activities.description: Single Tread Motor Bike Trail.  Most Difficult, Off U.S. Highway 12, forest road 1200. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Foggy Dew Trail #417
places.directions: From Twisp take State Route 20 east for 3 miles. At that point it joins with State Route 153. Take SR 153 to Okanogan County Road 1029. Turn onto County Road 1029. Next turn onto County Road 1034 until it joins with Forest Service Road 4340. Travel about 5 miles to FS Road 4340-200 turn left and travel about 4 miles to the trailhead.

activities.name: Foggy Dew Trail #417
activities.description: The trail parallels the creek, staying on the north side, starting off traveling through ponderosa pine and Douglas fir forest. The forest changes to lodgepole pine about 2.5 miles and again to subalpine-lodgepole pine mix at bout 3.5 miles to the end of the route. The trail is fairly flat most of the distance, but is rocky 3.5 miles to its end. At 5 miles the trail joins with the Martin Creek Trail #429 (right fork) and Foggy Dew Trail Section II #417A (left fork). source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: St. Edwards State Park
places.directions: Take 522 north towards Bothell. Make a right on 68 NE (which turns into Juanita Drive). 2-3 miles, turn right into St. Eds park. Park near rec center.

activities.name: St. Edwards State Park
activities.description:
Excellent single track. Lots of variety. Quite technical in places.
A good place to spend an hour or two. The trails are well maintained
by the Backcountry Bicycle Trails Club. Caution: The trails are multi-use
and can be somewhat busy at times. Watch out for hikers!

activities.name: St. Edwards State Park
activities.description: St. Edwards State Park features 5 miles of hiking trails near Kirkland, WA.

places.name: Skokomish Lower South Fork / Trail #873
places.directions: From Shelton travel north on US Highway 101 for 6 miles and turn west onto the Skokomish Valley Road. Travel 5.3 miles, then turn right onto Forest Service Road #23 and drive 9.0 miles to Forest Service Road #2353. Turn right onto Forest Service Road #2353 and drive 3/4 mile. After crossing the river, turn left and drive 0.2 mile to Skokomish Lower South Fork Trailhead (fee site)

activities.name: Skokomish Lower South Fork / Trail #873
activities.description: Trail leads through old growth forest paralleling the South Fork Skokomish River. Good trail for mountain bikes, horses, and fishing in the nearby river. Points of interest include the old LeBar Claim, Church Creek Shelter and Harps Shelter. This trail is gradual to moderate and travels 10.3 miles to the Skokomish Upper South Fork Trailhead. via fs.usda.gov

places.name: Naneum Meadows Trail #1389
places.directions: From Highway 97 at Swauk Pass, go south on FS Road 9716 to FS Road 9712, east on 9712, then south on Road 35 to the trailhead on top of Table Mountain.

activities.name: Naneum Meadows Trail #1389
activities.description: Descends gently through alternating meadows and stands of old-growth lodgepole pine. The trail descends more steeply, crosses FS Road 3530, and skirts lower Naneum Meadows. It then crosses Naneum Creek and ends at the junction with Trail #1381. This is an old trail, with some use by cattle, but it is in relatively good condition. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Pyramid Creek Trail #1439
places.directions: TBD

activities.name: Pyramid Creek Trail #1439
activities.description: The Pyramid Creek Trail begins at Trail #1437 and ends at Trail #1433.  Lower areas of the trail burned in the Pyramid Fire 2012 use caution when traveling through areas of burned trees and snags. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Old Stage Trail #1
places.directions: Use Old Stage Trailhead.

activities.name: Old Stage Trail #1
activities.description: A remaining segment of the first state highway in Washington, this trail is the only wagon trail in the forest trail system. This trail connects with Kettle Crest (North) National Recreation Trail #13. Can be made into a loop route with Midnight Ridge Trail #41. The trail in combination with Midnight Ridge Trail #41 makes a popular mountain bike loop. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Watmough Bay
places.directions: Drive south from Lopez Village on Fisherman Bay Road. Keep left onto Mud Bay Road, turn right at Aleck Bay Road, then left on Watmough Bay Road. Follow this road approximately 1 1/2 miles, then turn left at hte bottom of a small hill, at the Watmough Bay Sign. Please park in the trailhead parking area.
places.description: The protected Watmough Bay provides excellent recreational opportunities and many boaters and visitors enjoy its solitude and protection. An extensive eel grass and seaweed seafloor provide excellent habitat for juvenile Chinook salmon and other species which call this place home. Utilizing dinghies, sea kayaks and other non-motorized smaller skiffs visitors come to Watmough beach to relax, picnic, sightsee, and view wildlife. A trail from the trailhead parking area to the beach allows easy access for all visitors. Watmough Bay is cooperatively managed with the San Juan County Land Bank and San Juan Preservation Trust who share portions of the area and adjacent properties

activities.name: Watmough Bay
activities.description: Nice short trail.

places.name: Evans Creek ORV Area
places.directions: The Evans Creek ORV Area is located 25 miles South of Enumclaw. To reach it, follow State highway 410 four miles west to Buckley. Turn left onto State Highway 165 toward Wilkeson and Carbonado. The entrance to the ORV area is on the left side of the road.

activities.name: Evans Creek ORV Area
activities.description: Evans Creek Trailhead provides access to 40 miles of combined four-wheel drive and motorcycle/quad trails of varying difficulty.

places.name: Lower Dungeness / Trail #833.3
places.directions: Located at the end of Whiskey Bend Rd. off FS 2909.

activities.name: Lower Dungeness / Trail #833.3
activities.description:
This multi-use trail is within conifer forest above Dungeness River. Mossy rock outcrops and steep side slopes are found in the Three O'clock Ridge area, also some valley and mountain views.<br />
<br />
Mountain bikers are asked to avoid using the lower sections during wet weather due to soil types that can sustain a lot of damage. via fs.usda.gov

places.name: Frost Mountain Trail #1366
places.directions: From I-90 Exit 101, travel south and southeast on Thorp Highway for 2 miles, turn right onto Miller Road and follow it to the the junction with Robinson Canyon Road, where Miller changes to Cove Road. Follow Cove Road to the junction with Manastash Road and turn right and follow Manastash Road to the end of the pavement. Continue on FS Road 3100 beyond Buck Meadows to the trailhead.

activities.name: Frost Mountain Trail #1366
activities.description:
Steep and rocky tread makes it a very challenging bike ride.<br />
<br />
Heading north, the trail begins climbing immediately through a large clearcut (1989) for about 0.5 mile with Frost Mountain to the right, crosses a divide and begins a rapid descent to the South Fork Taneum Creek, which the trail crosses before ending on trail 1367 South Fork Taneum. Portions of the trail were reconstructed in 1979, but the trail is mostly steep and rugged. South from the trailhead, the trail follows the 3100-124 spur road for about 800 feet before heading off to the left into forest. The trail continues on a gentle up and down grade through trees, meadows and clearcuts for about a mile to its end at a junction with Shoestring Lake Trail 1385. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Kayak Point Regional County Park
places.directions: Exit 199 of I-5 at Marysville; turn left onto Marine Drive; follow Marine Drive for 13 miles; park is on the left.
places.description: A spectacular saltwater beach park located along the shores of picturesque Port Susan. From its 3,300 feet shoreline to its evergreen forests, Kayak Point Park offers a rich setting for pier fishing, windsurfing, picnicking, hiking, camping, and boat launching.   A pier extends 300 feet into Puget Sound and is the site for crabbing and fishing. At high tide, the water depth is 50 feet off the pier’s end. Baited crab pots are used to attract Dungeness and red rock crab.   Fishing enthusiasts catch flounder, sole, true cod, rockfish, and walleye pollock year-round and migrating sea perch in spring and summer. Casting from the shoreline will occasionally bring in dolly varden or a sea-run cutthroat.

activities.name: Kayak Point Regional County Park
activities.description: Nature trail.

activities.name: Kayak Point County Park
activities.description: A spectacular saltwater beach park located along the shores of picturesque Port Susan. From its 3,300 foot shoreline to its evergreen forests, Kayak Point Park offers a rich setting for pier fishing, windsurfing, picnicking, hiking, camping, and boat launching. A pier extends 300 feet into Puget Sound and is the site for crabbing and fishing. At high tide, the water depth is 50 feet off the pier&#39;s end. Baited crab pots are used to attract Dungeness and red rock crab.  Fishing enthusiasts catch flounder, sole, true cod, rockfish, and walleye Pollack year-round and migrating sea perch in Spring and Summer. Casting from the shoreline will occasionally bring in dolly varden or a sea-run cutthroat. A  single lane boat launch provides access to Port Susan.   The park is located on beautiful Puget Sound with views of Whidbey Island and Camano Island.

places.name: Columbia Mountain Loop / Trail #24
places.directions: From Kettle Crest Trailhead, travel north on Kettle Crest (North) National Recreation Trail #13 for 2 miles to junction of Columbia Mountain Loop Trail #24.

activities.description: This loop is described as one of the top snowshoe treks in the Columbia Highlands. Head north on the Kettle Crest National Scenic Trail across the southwestern flank of Columbia Mountain. The open summit, the high point for this adventure, holds views of the surrounding Kettle Range. Some previous snowshoe experience and winter survival skills recommended on this trail.

This loop is described as one of the top snowshoe treks in the Columbia Highlands. Head north on the Kettle Crest National Scenic Trail across the southwestern flank of Columbia Mountain. The open summit, the high point for this adventure, holds views of the surrounding Kettle Range. Some previous snowshoe experience and winter survival skills recommended on this trail.

places.name: Saint Edward State Park
places.directions: Located at the north end of Lake Washington in Kenmore, Wash. in King County.
places.description: Saint Edward State Park is a 316-acre day-use park with 3,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on Lake Washington. Once a Catholic seminary, the park's rich history reflects in its grounds and architecture. Walks along the undeveloped lakeshore are peaceful and give the visitor many opportunities for nature study.

activities.name: Saint Edward State Park
activities.description:
Hike through a diverse century-old second-growth forest with a dense canopy to the undeveloped shoreline of Lake Washington. This historic 316-acre state park, nestled in the midst of the Seattle metropolitan area, has playground facilities for children, picnic areas, trails for mountain bikers, and fields for sports teams as well.
Perhaps the most fascinating activity is hiking from the hills 400 feet above Lake Washington down to the undeveloped shoreline under a dense canopy of Douglas fir, western red cedar, western hemlock, bigleaf maple, Pacific madrona, and cottonwood.
Wildflowers and ground cover include sword ferns, devil’s club, candy flower, thimbleberry, red currant, Robert Geranium, Oregon grape, and bleeding heart. Be cautious of the Pacific banana slugs and European black slugs that outnumber hikers on the trail during the spring, summer, and fall months.

places.name: Triton Cove State Park
places.directions: Located on the Olympic Peninsula on the west side of Hood Canal, six miles south of Brinnon, Wash., and seven miles north of Eldon, Wash. in Jefferson County.
places.description: Triton Cove State Park is a 29-acre day-use park with 555 feet of saltwater shore on Hood Canal. This small park provides an ADA-compliant boat launch with access to near-shore fishing. Future plans include possible camping facilities.

places.name: Denny Creek
places.directions: From Seattle, take Interstate 90 east to exit 47. Go north over the freeway and follow signs 3 miles to campground.

activities.name: Denny Creek
activities.description: Situated near the south fork of the Snoqualmie River in Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, Denny Creek Campground offers visitors stunning scenery and easy access to an abundance of recreational activities in the Northern Cascade Range.      Campsites sit beneath a canopy of forest, and a few are sprinkled at the banks of Lodge Creek, which flows into the Snoqualmie.

places.name: Fauntleroy Park
places.description: Open from 6 a.m. - 10 p.m., Fauntleroy Park is a densely wooded patch of forest located near Fauntleroy Cove in West Seattle.

activities.name: Fauntleroy Park
activities.description:
Open from 6 a.m. - 10 p.m., Fauntleroy Park is a densely wooded patch of forest located near Fauntleroy Cove in West Seattle.

There is a network of paths that run throughout the park, which are perfect for hiking, dog-walking, or just strolling on a lunch break. The trails total about 1.5 miles in length.

places.name: Lawton Park
places.directions: Heading North on I-5:<br /><br />    Take the Mercer St exit<br />    Go right at first stoplight<br />    At next set of stoplights go left<br />    Stay in far right lane that merges onto Westlake Ave N.<br />    Follow Westlake until you reach the Nickerson St.<br />    Go straight on Nickerson St past Fremont Bridge and Seattle Pacific University.<br />    Staying in left lane follow the sign to the Ballard Bridge/Emerson St.<br />    At 3 way stop take a left onto a ½ circle viaduct and follow Emerson<br />    Emerson becomes W Thurman St.<br />    Turn right onto 24th Ave W<br />    Then, take an immediate left onto  W Thurman<br />    Turn left onto 26TH Ave W.
places.description: Visitors to Lawton Park can enjoy leisurely strolls down a wide pathway that carries the visitor through hills, woods and grassy lawns. There is also a dirt path that winds its way around maple trees and leads to three old picnic tables, as well as more primitive paths blazed by neighborhood children.

activities.name: Lawton Park
activities.description: Visitors to Lawton Park can enjoy leisurely strolls down a wide pathway that carries the visitor through hills, woods and grassy lawns. There is also a dirt path that winds its way around maple trees and leads to three old picnic tables, as well as more primitive paths blazed by neighborhood children.

places.name: Freund Creek
places.directions: From downtown Leavenworth, take Chemstick Highway North until just before the railway bridge.  Take a left towards Freund Canyon (there is a sign) and follow this road until the pavement ends.  You can park there and take the dirt road up about 1-1.5 miles.  Don't take the lower trail on the left.  This is the downhill portion  which is very fast and would lead to a nasty collision.  Continue up the road until you see the sign for the trailhead.

activities.name: Freund Creek
activities.description: This trail has a steady climb winding through the canyon and offers wonderful views.  Once you get to the meadow the trail forks,  Take the right fork.  Take a short break at the top, then follow the main trail down.  Be sure to have your breaks checked prior to this ride.  The downhill portion is smooth, fast and dotted with multiple washout jumps to catch plenty of air.  There are even several large burms to carve on the way down.  Have fun!!!!

places.name: Gold Creek Trail #966
places.directions: The trail begins at end of  Forest Service Road 1703 off State Route 410 and ends at Trail #694.

activities.name: Gold Creek Trail #966
activities.description: The trail begins at Forest Service Road 1703 and ends at Trail #694.  Intermediate. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Pacific Pines State Park
places.directions: Located approximately one mile north of Ocean Park, Wash. in Pacific Pines.
places.description: Pacific Pines State Park sits on the Pacific shore. The area is conducive to all manner of day-trip beach activity and nature observation.

places.name: Hope Island State Park (Skagit)
places.directions: The park is accessible only both boat.<br />1.5 miles southeast of Hoypus Point, about two miles east then southeast on Cornet Bay boat launch.
places.description: Hope Island (north) State Park is a 200-acre marine park in Skagit Bay. The park offers several campsites, attractive beaches and a trail across the island. The island is forested with occasional meadows and rock outcroppings.

activities.name: Hope Island State Park (Skagit)
activities.description: Hope Island (north) State Park is a 200-acre marine park in Skagit Bay. The park offers several campsites, attractive beaches and a trail across the island. The island is forested with occasional meadows and rock outcroppings.

places.name: McMicken Island State Park
places.directions: McMicken Island is situated on the east side of Harstine Island in Case Inlet in Mason County. The park is only reachable by boat.
places.description: McMicken Island State Park is an 11.5 acre marine park with 1,661 feet of saltwater shoreline. It is situated in the beautiful South Puget Sound and features a pristine cove to set anchor. Visitors can enjoy the many hiking trails, viewing an active bald eagle nest and shellfish harvesting. The shellfish population is abundant and open to shellfish harvesters year round.

activities.name: McMicken Island State Park
activities.description: McMicken Island State Park is an 11.5 acre marine park with 1,661 feet of saltwater shoreline. It is situated in the beautiful South Puget Sound and features a pristine cove to set anchor. Visitors can enjoy the many hiking trails, viewing an active bald eagle nest and shellfish harvesting. The shellfish population is abundant and open to shellfish harvesters year round.

activities.name: McMicken Island State Park
activities.description: The park is available for day use only, but five moorage buoys are available for overnight stays.

places.name: Meadowdale Beach Park
places.directions: 164th Street SW exit off I-5; follow 164th St SW west to 164th SW; turn right to cross Hwy 99; turn right onto 52nd Ave W; turn left onto 160th St; turn right onto 56th Ave W; turn left onto 156th Ave W. Park entrance is at the end of the road.
places.description: Stroll through the park's corridor on a 1-1/4 mile long nature trail.  Experience the sounds of the adjacent tumbling stream as it weaves its way through the giant trees of the old forest.  The stream, which is home to various aquatic life, including fresh water fish and migrating salmon, forms a small marine estuary as it empties into Puget Sound. Meadowdale Beach Park, 108 acres,  is beautiful, but delicate, not impervious to humans and natural calamity.  Its care and preservation are imperative to wildlife and the balance of people with nature is not possible without vigilance.

activities.name: Meadowdale Beach Park
activities.description: View various bird species in their natural habitat on a hike through the forest.  Or comb the beaches and enjoy the breathtaking views of the distant Olympic Mountains.

places.name: Falls Creek
places.directions: North from Carson on WA 30 to pass. Singletrack to the east.

activities.name: Falls Creek
activities.description: Ride thru deep forest. Heavy moss on some of the trees. Trail ends back at the highway lower and to the south of start after paralleling a river. Highly scenic.

places.name: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area
places.directions: From Spokane or Seattle, the Grand Coulee and Fort Spokane areas of Lake Roosevelt are easy drive north from US Highway 2 (US 2). From Spokane, the Kettle Falls region can be reached from US Highway 395 North (US 395). From the Okanogan River valley, Kettle Falls can be reached from State Route 20 East (SR 20).<br /><br />Source: National Park Service

activities.name: Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area
activities.description:
Four self-guided walking trails in the park will take you back in time so you can explore the history and geology of Lake Roosevelt or simply enjoy the beauty of it's diverse scenery and terrain.<br />
Mission Point Trail: Only one-mile from the Kettle Falls Campground, at St. Paul's Mission, a 1/4 mile trail combines history and nature. There are signs along the trail explaining the history of the falls, the mission, and the Hudson's Bay Company's influence on the area.The view of the river is rivaled only by the abundance of plants you will find along the trail.<br />
Source: National Park Service
Hawk Creek Hike 4.5 miles
This is one of those places where timing is everything. The big late winter/early spring drawdown of Lake Roosevelt is probably one of the best times to go. This way you can hike along the beaches of Hawk Creek just as folks did 10,000 years ago. You probably won’t make it to the Columbia River confluence, but you’ll get close enough to see it. If you head out when the water levels are high, there are still some upland hikes that treat you to some pretty spectacular pre and post-Pleistocene landforms (glacial terraces at several levels, Missoula Flood remnants, basalt escarpments, even pillow basalts over 5 million years old!) Numerous deer trails and old roads and trails (unmarked) easily get you around up here.
This is a great little trek under 5 miles RT, with about 900’ overall elevation gain. It was pretty muddy on the way in but gets better up high. The views are spectacular, the wildlife abounds, and the serenity is hard to beat.

places.name: Squilchuck State Park
places.directions: Located nine miles southwest of Wenatchee, Wash., up Squilchuck Canyon toward Mission Ridge in Chelan County.
places.description: Squilchuck State Park is a 288-acre park covered with forests of fir and ponderosa pine. The park sits below Mission Ridge at an elevation of 3,200 feet. A group camp is available by reservations for groups of 20 or more. The Squilchuck Lodge and group camp also may be reserved for day-use events for groups between May and October. The lodge is very popular for weddings, reunions and other group activities.

activities.name: Squilchuck State Park
activities.description: Park trails are open to day visitors who walk or bicycle into the park. However, when the campground or lodge is reserved, day visitors are not permitted in the campground or lodge area. Please respect the privacy of groups that have reserved the park.

activities.name: Squilchuck State Park
activities.description: The park has one group camp that accommodates up to 100 guests (minimum of 20 guests). There are men's and women's restrooms, with one shower in each restroom. There are no RV hookups, and campsites are designed to accommodate tents and cars or smaller RVs. Fees vary with size of the group. Reservations are required.

places.name: Marten Creek
places.directions: From Seattle, Washington, go north on I-5 toward Everett. Take exit 194 ontoHighway 2. At Highway 204 turn north toward Lake Stevens. Turn north on Highway 9, theneast on Highway 92 to Granite Falls.  From Granite Falls take Highway 7 Scenic east for about 20 miles to the campground.

activities.name: Marten Creek
activities.description: Visitors traversing the scenic Mountain Loop Road through Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest will find Marten Creek Group Campground.      Located on a forested bench above the confluence of the tranquil Stillaguamish River and Marten Creek, this campground is in close proximity to several wilderness areas and a handful of hiking trails, offering visitors opportunities to experience both the serene and wild aspects of the Cascade region.

places.name: Jones Island State Park
places.directions: Jones Island State Park is reachable only by boat. The park is located one mile west of the southwest tip of Orcas Island in San Juan County.
places.description: Jones Island State park is a 188-acre marine camping park with 25,000 feet of saltwater shoreline on the San Jaun channel. The park features a beautiful loop trail down the center of the island then around the western shore.

activities.name: Jones Island State Park
activities.description: Jones Island State park is a 188-acre marine camping park with 25,000 feet of saltwater shoreline on the San Jaun channel. The park features a beautiful loop trail down the center of the island then around the western shore.

places.name: Pacific Crest Trail: J: I-90 (Snoqualmie Pass) to Hwy 2 (Stevens Pass)
places.directions: wa

activities.name: Pacific Crest Trail: J: I-90 (Snoqualmie Pass) to Hwy 2 (Stevens Pass)
activities.description:
Section J of the Pacific Crest Trail runs 74.7 miles from I-90 at Snoqualmie Pass to Highway 2 at Stevens Pass. This section runs through gorgeous Cascade Mountains backcountry. Most of the beauty of this section is protected by the Alpine Lakes Wilderness.<br />
<br />
Along the way this section of trail passes Huckleberry Saddle, Needle Sight Gap, Chikamin Pass, Delate Creek, Lemah Creek, Waptus River, Deep Lake, Cathedral Pass, Deception Pass, Pieper Pass, Trap Pass, Trap Lake, Hope Lake, Mig Lake, Lake Susan Jane, and Stevens Pass ski area.

places.name: Big Finn Hill
places.directions: Take 522 north towards Bothell. Make a right on 68 NE (which turns into Juanita Drive). 2-3 miles, turn right into St. Eds park. Park near rec center.

activities.name: Big Finn Hill
activities.description: Located just to the south of St. Edwards. Several long circular routes. Some exciting down-hill sprints leading to very challenging up-hill grunt work. A couple of nice jumps can be found. Watch out for dogs walking their masters!

activities.name: Big Finn Hill
activities.description: Big Finn Hill features 5 miles of hiking trails near Kirkland, WA.

places.name: greenlake
places.directions: 145 th & stone way, soccer fields

activities.name: Greenlake
activities.description: dirt jumps not for faint hearted, skatepark, fields, a little single track

places.name: Edgewater Campground
places.directions: The campground is located approximately 90 miles north of Spokane, WA. After crossing the Ione Bridge eastbound over the Pend Oreille River, look for theEdgewater Campground sign and immediately turn left. The campground is located 2 miles north of the bridge on Box Canyon Road.

activities.name: Edgewater Campground
activities.description: Edgewater Campground is perched along the banks of the Pend Oreille River in the Colville National Forest. The quiet, family-friendly campground attracts visitors who come for boating, hiking and fishing. The picturesque area, surrounded by cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir, boasts views of the Selkirk Mountains.

places.name: North Fork Twentymile Trail #560
places.directions: From Winthrop drive the West Chewuch Road north about 20 miles to Camp Four Campground. Cross the bridge on Forest Service Road 5110. In 0.5 miles turn left on Forest Service Road 700. Drive 2.0 miles to the trailhead.

activities.name: North Fork Twentymile Trail #560
activities.description:
The trail is open to mountain bikes, but due to its steepness it should be considered a "most difficult" route.<br />
<br />
The first 0.5 miles of trail is on the old road bed. The trail begins in timber and maintains a steady uphill climb as it ascends the valley of Honeymoon Creek. Much of this trail burned over in a 2006 wildfire. The upper portion of the trail is above timberline. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Madrona Park
places.description: Open from 4:00 a.m.- 11:30 p.m., Madrona Beach offers beautiful views overlooking the waterfront on Lake Washington.

activities.name: Madrona Park
activities.description:
Open from 4:00 a.m.- 11:30 p.m., Madrona Park offers beautiful views overlooking the waterfront on Lake Washington. It has a wooded hillside that leads into a grassy beach and swimming area; lifeguards are on duty during the summertime. The park features a jogging path that winds along Lake Washington, as well as picnic areas for visitors to enjoy.

A network of hiking trails, totaling 1 mile, runs through the wooded section of the park.

places.name: Wenberg County Park
places.directions: From I-5, head west on Hwy 531 at exit 206.  Approximately 2.25 miles from I-5 turn right at stopsign.  Road is a continuation of Hwy 531 (also referred to as Lakewood Rd.).  Follow Lakewood Rd for approximately 2.4 miles to East Lake Goodwin Rd.  Turn left onto East Lake Goodwin Rd. and follow approximately 1 mile to park entrance on your right.
places.description: Located on the eastern shore of Lake Goodwin, Wenberg Park offers splendid opportunities for picnicking, sunbathing, boating, and camping.

activities.name: Wenberg County Park
activities.description: Located on the eastern shore of Lake Goodwin, this 45 acre park offers water access,  camping, two picnic shelters, playground, 465 feet of swim beach, 1,140 feet of freshwater shoreline, a concession stand, a two-lane concrete boat launch and walking trails. Management of the park was transferred to Snohomish County from the Washington State Parks and Recreation Commission on July 16, 2009.

places.name: Palouse Falls State Park
places.directions: Located 23 miles southeast of Washtucna, Wash. in Franklin County.
places.description: Palouse Falls State Park is a 105-acre camping park with a unique geology and history. The park offers a dramatic view of one of the state's most beautiful waterfalls. Palouse Falls drops from a height of 198 feet with high volumes of water flow in spring and early summer.

activities.name: Palouse Falls State Park
activities.description: The quarter-mile ADA-accessible hiking trail overlooks the falls.

activities.name: Palouse Falls State Park
activities.description: Palouse Falls State Park is a 105-acre camping park with a unique geology and history. The park offers a dramatic view of one of the state's most beautiful waterfalls. Palouse Falls drops from a height of 198 feet with high volumes of water flow in spring and early summer.

places.name: Stuart Island State Park
places.directions: The park is reachable only by boat. The nearest access is four miles southeast at Roche Harbor Resort on San Juan Island. The entrance to Reid Harbor is partially blocked by two small islands. Boaters should keep these islands to their starboard when entering the harbor.
places.description: Stuart Island State Park is an 85-acre marine camping park with 33,030 feet of shoreline. The park is part of the Cascadia Marine Trail and offers camping and moorage at Reed and Prevost harbors. Some campsites are for the exclusive use of those arriving by human- or wind-powered watercraft.

activities.name: Stuart Island State Park
activities.description: Stuart Island State Park is an 85-acre marine camping park with 33,030 feet of shoreline. The park is part of the Cascadia Marine Trail and offers camping and moorage at Reed and Prevost harbors. Some campsites are for the exclusive use of those arriving by human- or wind-powered watercraft.

activities.name: Stuart Island State Park
activities.description: Stuart Island State Park is an 85-acre marine camping park with 33,030 feet of shoreline. The park is part of the Cascadia Marine Trail and offers camping and moorage at Reed and Prevost harbors. Some campsites are for the exclusive use of those arriving by human- or wind-powered watercraft.

places.name: Middle Tommy Trail #1424
places.directions: TBD

activities.name: Middle Tommy Trail #1424
activities.description: The Middle Tommy Trail begins at Forest Service Road 5100, Lake Creek Trailhead and ends at Trail #1426. This trail has a dangerous ford at Tommy Creek early in the season during peak runoff. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Estes Butte Trail #1527
places.directions: The trail begins at the Estes Butte Trailhead located 15 miles North on the Chiwawa Valley Road #6200.

activities.name: Estes Butte Trail #1527
activities.description: This trail has moderate grades leading to the old Estes Butte fire lookout site. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Merritt Lake Trail #1588
places.directions: The trail begins at the Merritt Lake Trailhead located off Highway 2 near milepost 76. The trail ends at the junction with the Nason Ridge Trail #1583 which continues to Merritt Lake.

activities.name: Merritt Lake Trail #1588
activities.description: This trail accesses Nason Ridge and Merritt Lake. The trail has moderate grades with numerous switchbacks. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Section 36 (Beaver Lake)
places.directions: From I-9,0 take the Issaquah Front Street exit. Head North under the freeway onto E Lake Samamish. At the second stop light, turn right onto Issaquah-Fall City Rd and head up the hill. At the second stop light, continue straight onto Issaquah-Pine Lake Rd. Follow Issaquah-Pine Lake Rd to its end and turn right onto 228th Ave SE. Continue on 228th Ave until you reach SE 8th St. Take a right on SE 8th St and follow it back (it dips down and curves north where the road turns into 244th Ave SE) until you come to E Main Drive. Turn right on Main Dr and follow it to its end at the parking lot. (Road becomes E Plateau Dr along the way.)

activities.name: Section 36 (Beaver Lake)
activities.description: Nice, well maintained single track. Good for beginners. Most intersections are marked with maps.

activities.name: Section 36 (Beaver Lake)
activities.description: Section 36 (Beaver Lake) features 12 miles of hiking trails near Sammamish, WA.

places.name: Thorp Creek Trail #1316
places.directions: From I-90 Exit 80, go through Roslyn on Highway 903 to Lake Cle Elum, along the lake to FS Road 4308, west on 4308 to 4312, and northwest on 4312 to the trailhead which is at a gate on FS Road 4312-121. Walk along this road, crossing Thorp Creek at a ford, approximately 0.25 mile to trail.

activities.name: Thorp Creek Trail #1316
activities.description: Parallels Thorp Creek through a partial cut forabout 1.5 miles, gradually getting farther from the creek until the junction with Thorp Lake Trail which runs for 0.25 miles to the lake. Trail 1316 ends 0.5 miles further at the junction with Kachess Ridge Trail 1315. This is a nice trail, but it gets steep for the last mile. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Stevens Pass Bike Park
places.directions: On hwy 2 / Stevens pass hwy

activities.name: Stevens Pass Bike Park
activities.description: Lift assisted access to 6 trails suiting a range of abilities,with more planned for the future.

places.name: Gillette Ridge Trail System #131
places.directions: Trailheads are located at Roger Mountain, Clinton Creek Forest Camp, and Onion Creek.<br /><br />Roger Mountain: Travel state Route 20 one mile east of Colville. Turn north on county road 9435 and follow for 19 miles. Take Forest Service road 500 for 6.4 miles to trailhead.

activities.name: Gillette Ridge Trail System #131
activities.description:
Two loop trails are included in this multi-purpose trail system. Scenic mountain views. Ruins of a fire lookout on Rogers Mountain.<br />
<br />
Share the trail with hikers and OHVs. Difficulty: "easy to more difficult." souce: fs.usda.gov

places.name: South Fork Silver Creek Trail #123
places.directions: From Colville follow county road 9435 north for 23 miles and take county road 9445 to Leadpoint. Turn east at Leadpoint and follow Forest Service road 4720 to the junction with road 070. Continue east on road 070 to the trailhead.

activities.name: South Fork Silver Creek Trail #123
activities.description:
This wooded trail crosses several creeks. Views of the Pend Oreille Valley and the Kettle Crest. Variable weather conditions. Layered clothing, contour maps, survival kit, and ample food and water are recommended.<br />
<br />
Fantastic views of valley below.<br />
Can access trail #117. Difficulty level: most difficult. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Gibbs Lake County Park
places.directions: From Highway 19 in Chimacum, WA, heading North, turn left onto West Valley Rd next to Chimacum High School. At mile post 4 turn right onto Gibbs Lake Rd. Follow road as it transitions to gravel. Look for parking lots on the right.

activities.name: Gibbs Lake County Park
activities.description: Twisty, rooty, single-track through the woods. Trail is shared with hikers, horses, and dogs. Be courteous.

activities.name: Ape Cave
activities.description: Spectacular lava cave located at the foot of Mount Hood. The ranger station at the cave entrance rents lanterns and flashlights (check for hours of operation). The entrance is accessible with stairs and walkways leading into the main tunnel. The tunnel leads down to a dead end on one end while the other end features a second entrance/exit to the cave. Roughly 3 miles of passageways (round trip).

activities.name: Ape Cave
activities.description: Spectacular lava cave located at the foot of Mount Hood. The ranger station at the cave entrance rents lanterns and flashlights (check for hours of operation). The entrance is accessible with stairs and walkways leading into the main tunnel. The tunnel leads down to a dead end on one end while the other end features a second entrance/exit to the cave. Roughly 3 miles of passageways (round trip).

places.name: Sun Top
places.directions: Take Hwy 410 out of Enumclaw towards Mt Ranier to milepost 47, turn rt on FR 73. After crossing <br />White River...park on the right at dirt pullout (Trailhead for Skookum Flats).

activities.name: Sun Top
activities.description:
Climb the gravel road for 5.7 miles and 3,000+ feet elevation, to where trail crosses the road.
Turn left onto singletrack to start the ride, or continue on the gravel road to the summit of Sun
Top (another mile and 1,000') for really nice views from the lookout of Mt Ranier et all,
singletrack off the summit comes back to where the trail crosses the road at the 5.7 mile mark.
Climb the trail for the next mile...then ~8 Miles of mostly downhill singletrack to the White River
(not real technical, but smooth and fast and beautiful scenery). Return via Skookum Flats Trail
5.5 miles of technical singletrack to the car to complete loop.

activities.name: Sun Top
activities.description: Sun Top features 21 miles of hiking trails near Greenwater, WA.

places.name: Middle Fork Campground
places.directions: From Interstate 5 north going toward Seattle, take Interstate 90 east toward North Bend. Take exit 34 and turn north on 468th Ave. Turn right onto SE Middle Fork Road/Forest Service Road 56. Continue about 12 miles to the campground, located about 1/2 a mile past the Middle Fork Trailhead.

activities.name: Middle Fork Campground
activities.description: This campground is located along the Middle Fork of the scenic Snoqualmie River in Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest.      Beneath a canopy of towering Douglas fir, cedar and Western hemlock, and located near several hiking trails within a short     driving distance, this campground is a perfect site for both individual and small group camping excursions.

places.name: Illahee State Park
places.directions: Take East Bremerton exit at north end of Silverdale. Follow road to Sylvan Way (about 7.5 miles). Take a left and drive to park entrance (about 1.5 miles).
places.description: Illahee State Park is a 75-acre marine camping park with 1,785 feet of saltwater frontage on Port Orchard Bay. "Illahee" means "earth" or "country" in the Indian tradition, and views of Puget Sound from the Illahee beach give the viewer a sense of what that word meant to native people. The park has plenty of parking space, lots of fresh air, facilities for a number of outdoor activities and access to a variety of water sports.

activities.name: Illahee State Park
activities.description: A veterans' war memorial is located in the park. Several interpretive displays are available that explain park features such as stilted trees, a Works Progress Administration-built kitchen shelter, totem garden, yew tree and the pier.

activities.name: Illahee State Park
activities.description: Illahee State Park is a 75-acre marine camping park with 1,785 feet of saltwater frontage on Port Orchard Bay. "Illahee" means "earth" or "country" in the Indian tradition, and views of Puget Sound from the Illahee beach give the viewer a sense of what that word meant to native people. The park has plenty of parking space, lots of fresh air, facilities for a number of outdoor activities and access to a variety of water sports.

places.name: Flowing Lake Park at Leckie's Beach
places.directions: Snohomish-Wenatchee exit off I-5 onto US2 in Everett. At milepost 10 turn left onto 100th St SE (Westwick Road). Just past the French Creek Grange, the road bears sharply to the left (north) and becomes 171st Ave. SE Continue on 171st Ave SE to 48th St SE; turn right onto 48th St SE. Park entrance is at the end of the road.
places.description: Flowing Lake offers a multitude of year-round recreation activities.The campground contains over 30 campsites, most include water and electrical hookups. The ranger staff presents interpretive programs in the rustic amphitheater and guided nature walks throughout the summer season. Many picnic tables and picnic shelters are available.

activities.name: Flowing Lake Park at Leckie
activities.description: Nature trail.

activities.name: Flowing Lake Park at Leckie
activities.description: Flowing Lake offers a multitude of year-round recreation activities.The campground contains over 30 campsites, most include water and electrical hookups. The ranger staff presents interpretive programs in the rustic amphitheater and guided nature walks throughout the summer season. Many picnic tables and picnic shelters are available.

places.name: Cooper Glance Trail #519
places.directions: From Winthrop drive north on Okanogan County Road 1213 to Eightmile Ranch. Take a left onto Forest Service Road 5130 (Eightmile Creek Road) and drive 13 miles to the signed trailhead.

activities.name: Cooper Glance Trail #519
activities.description: The first part of the trail follows the old jeep trail that  provides access to the Copper Glance mining claimants. At 1.5 miles the jeep trail ends and Copper Glance Trail begins. The trail is steep and rocky in places and several streams must be forded. Not recommended for stock as an old bridge collapsed and there is not a good crossing for stock. Hikers need to use caution when crossing during high water. Reach the lake in just over 3 miles. Limited parking space at trailhead. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Little Goose Lock & Dam, Lake Bryan
places.directions: 9 miles northeast of Starbuck, Washington, on Little Goose Dam Road.

activities.name: Little Goose Lock & Dam, Lake Bryan
activities.description: Lake Bryan, located in southeastern Washington along the remote lower Snake River, provides for water fun and relaxation.  The landscape is characteristic of wide-open vistas with steep canyon walls and few trees.  The climate is arid.  Popular activities include fish viewing, boating, camping, swimming, water-skiing, hunting and fishing.  Recreation facilities include picnic areas and semi-primitive campgrounds.  A full service campground is found at nearby Central Ferry Park 11.5 miles north of Dodge, Washington, on Highway 127.  Though closer to Lower Granite Lake (just below the Dam) Whitman County Boyer Park and Marina is located on the north shore of Lake Bryan. This area is along the Lewis and Clark route.

places.name: Moss Creek Campground
places.directions: 45.7948N 121.6329W.  From I-5 at Vancouver turn east on Highway 14 for 50 miles to Cook. North on County Road 1000 for 8 miles to campground on Forest Road 18.

activities.name: Moss Creek Campground
activities.description: A nice campground down by the creek. Paved road to campground. Generally small campsites but useable by smaller RVs. Close to Columbia River Gorge.

places.name: Chief Joseph Dam and Rufus Woods Lake
places.directions: Chief Joseph Dam is located in Bridgeport, WA. From Grand Coulee, drive 22 miles west on WA 174 to WA 17. Drive 16 miles west on WA 17 to the Columbia River. Or from Wenatchee, WA, drive 73 miles north on US 97, then 8 miles east on WA 17.
places.description: With a total of 27 generating units, Chief Joseph Dam is the second-largest hydropower producer in the United States -- second only to Grand Coulee Dam. The power plant produces enough power to supply the electrical needs of over 1.5 million people.

activities.name: Chief Joseph Dam and Rufus Woods Lake
activities.description: With a total of 27 generating units, Chief Joseph Dam is the second-largest hydropower producer in the United States -- second only to Grand Coulee Dam. The power plant produces enough power to supply the electrical needs of over 1.5 million people.

activities.name: Chief Joseph Dam And Rufus Woods Lake
activities.description: The visitor center features a view within the nation`s largest straightline powerhouse as well as interpretive displays.  Bridgeport State Park, including the Lake Woods Golf Course, is adjacent to the project.

places.name: Big Pines
places.directions: From Ellensburg, Washington, take Hwy 821 (Canyon Road) south through the Yakima River Canyon. Big Pines is located at milepost 10.
places.description: Big Pines is located in the scenic Yakima River Canyon, which cuts through massive basalt cliffs and rolling desert hills, 19 miles south of Ellensburg, Washington. This canyon has been designated as a state scenic route and offers excellent wildlife viewing, fishing in a Blue Ribbon trout stream, family river rafting and camping. At 20 acres, Big Pines is BLM's largest recreation site in the Yakima River Canyon. The northern edge of the recreation site is adjacent to undeveloped hiking trails on lands managed by the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife.

activities.name: Big Pines
activities.description: Excellent hiking.

activities.name: Big Pines
activities.description: Season Dates:  1/1 - 12/31.

places.name: Dutch Miller Gap / Trail #1030
places.directions: From North Bend, Wash,. travel east on I-90 for to exit 34. Then follow 468th Avenue north. In 0.6 miles turn right onto the Middle Fork Road (Forest Service road 56). Stay on Forest Service road 56 for 12.0 miles, at which point it veers to the right. Continue for another 5.0 miles; the parking area is on the right side of the road and the Dutch Miller Gap Trailhead is on the left.

activities.name: Dutch Miller Gap / Trail #1030
activities.description:
Starting at the Dutch Miller Gap Trailhead (at Dingford Creek) gate, horseman, cyclists and hikers travel along the closed portion of Forest Service Road 56 following the north side of the Middle Fork Snoqualmie River. Pass a junction with the spur trail to Middle Fork Trail 1003 and Goldmyer Hot Springs and cross a foot bridge on the south side of the Middle Fork River at milepost 4.5.<br />
From here the road climbs steeply to Hardscrabble Horse Camp with open views of rockslides, waterfalls and jagged peaks. At about 7.7 miles the road/trail ends at the horse camp. Bicycles are not allowed beyond this point. via fs.usda.gov

places.name: Dash Point State Park
places.directions: Located on the west side of Federal Way, Wash., in the vicinity of Seattle and Tacoma, in King County.
places.description: Dash Point State Park is situated on Puget Sound in Western Washington and is a popular destination for water recreation. This 398-acre camping park features 3,301 feet of saltwater shoreline. The beach provides unobstructed views of the Puget Sound and opportunities for sea-life study. The sandy beach at the park is a relaxing beach getaway near the cities of Seattle, Tacoma and Federal Way.

activities.name: Dash Point State Park
activities.description: single track..  well over all this is a good trail system one of the best marked trail systems i have ever ridden. there are even maps at the ranger station.  if you park of at one of the small side streets you do not have to pay to park either.  it is a good ride but be sure to get a map and ride the loop up heart attack.  then down the log run.

activities.name: Dash Point State Park
activities.description: Dash Point State Park features 11 miles of hiking trails near Tacoma, WA.

activities.name: Dash Point State Park
activities.description: Dash Point State Park is situated on Puget Sound in Western Washington and is a popular destination for water recreation. This 398-acre camping park features 3,301 feet of saltwater shoreline. The beach provides unobstructed views of the Puget Sound and opportunities for sea-life study. The sandy beach at the park is a relaxing beach getaway near the cities of Seattle, Tacoma and Federal Way.

places.name: Lake West
places.directions: Located 41.5 miles northeast of Pasco, Washington, on Pasco-Kahlotus Road to Kahlotus, WA, then 6 miles south on Devil's Conyon Road.
places.description: Lake West is located in southeastern Washington on the Lower Snake River. It is surrounded by a large, secluded fertile agricultural land base that provides very scenic views and there are recreational opportunities here for hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

activities.name: Lake West
activities.description: Lake West is located in southeastern Washington on the Lower Snake River. It is surrounded by a large, secluded fertile agricultural land base that provides very scenic views and there are recreational opportunities here for hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

activities.name: Lake West
activities.description: Lake West is located in southeastern Washington on the Lower Snake River. It is surrounded by a large, secluded fertile agricultural land base that provides very scenic views and there are recreational opportunities here for hiking, swimming, boating, fishing, canoeing, kayaking and camping.

places.name: North-Ridge
places.directions: Email Stan for directions.

activities.name: North-Ridge
activities.description: "The upper trailhead has a parking area. From here the trail drops into a rocky draw before climbing to the ridgetop via a series of switchbacks. Once on the ridgetop it mostly follows along the ridgetop crossing the high point of North Ridge where the remains of an old lookout may be seen. It then continues south to the junction with Mt. Clifty Trail #1321.1 approximately 0.25 miles before the trail ends at the junction with Cle Elum Ridge Trail #1326. Good idea to check with the Cle Elum Ranger District before riding this one due to snow. This is a long trail but mostly in good shape. It has a fun rating of 8 if your conditioning is a ten. Elevation goes from 2400 to 5900 plus some ups and downs. Campground closest to the north end of the trail is Lake Easton State Park.

places.name: Anacortes Community Forest Lands
places.directions: From I5, head west towards Anacortes on Highway 20 in Burlington. Get on Comercial and head down about 3-4 blocks to Anacortes Cyclery. Ask the guys in there directions to the Anacortes Community Forest Land. (I use the back route, but it is way to complicated)

activities.name: Anacortes Community Forest Lands
activities.description: There is a little of everything here. I did find a couple of nice downhill runs, but I was riding an XC bike so it was more challenging. My advice is to plan to make a day of it and explore, you should find what you are looking for. The trails are shared with horses, but the droppings won't bother you if you don't fall!

activities.name: Anacortes Community Forest Lands
activities.description: Anacortes Community Forest Lands features 20 miles of hiking trails near Anacortes, WA.

places.name: Keller Ferry Campground
places.directions: Take Highway 2 west of Spokane for 54 miles to the town of Wilbur, Washington. Turn north on Highway 21 (follow road signs). Travel 14 miles to the campground.

activities.name: Keller Ferry Campground
activities.description: Boaters, fishermen, swimmers and families love this shoreline retreat along Lake Roosevelt. The 130-mile lake is a feature of the Columbia River created by the Grand Coulee Dam. Keller Ferry is part of the Lake Roosevelt National Recreation Area, named after President Franklin D. Roosevelt and managed by the National Park Service.      Campers have the convenience of a swimming beach within a short walk of the campsites, a boat ramp within the facility and plenty of space to sit back and soak up the summer sun or relax during the cooler days of spring and fall.

places.name: North Creek County Park
places.directions: From I-5 southbound take EXIT 186, turn left onto 128TH ST SW / WA-96.  Turn right onto 16th Ave SE, turn right onto Bothell-Everett Hwy / WA-527.  Turn right onto 183rd St SE, park entrance is on the right.  From I-5 northbound take EXIT 183, keep right at the fork to go on 164th St SW, turn right onto Bothell-Everett Hwy / WA-527, turn right onto 183rd St SE, park entrance is on the right.

activities.name: North Creek County Park
activities.description: This beautiful expansive wetland park is nestled in the community of Mill Creek, an urban area. The sensitive wildlife habitat and diverse plant community serves multiple functions of flood control.  The network of boardwalks and trails provides excellent opportunities for bird watching and appreciating the ecosystem.  Close to shopping and dining with easy access to   I-5.  Bring a picnic and take a hike with your family.    Park History    The property was originally owned by the Bailey family, historic homesteaders. The county parks department and Surface Water Management targeted the site as a regional stormwater detention facility. The site was later developed with an interpretive boardwalk.

places.name: Crawford State Park
places.directions: Located 11 miles north of Metaline, Wash., in the extreme northeastern corner of the state in Pend Oreille County.
places.description: Crawford State Park is a 49-acre, forested day-use park featuring Gardner Cave, the third longest limestone cavern in Washington. This tourable cave is filled with stalactites, stalagmites, rimstone pools and flow stone.

activities.name: Crawford State Park
activities.description: The main activity at Crawford State Park is touring Gardner Cave. With large groups and holidays, extra tours can be given. Park staff limits tour size to 25 people. A call before arrival will help in accommodating large groups. Phone Crawford State Park at 509-446-4065, or Mount Spokane State Park at 509-238-4258.

activities.name: Crawford State Park
activities.description:
State Parks officially opened the Crawford Oaks trailhead at Columbia Hills State Park on May 17th of 2014. The trailhead is just east of Horsethief Butte on Hwy 14.
The trail is non-motorized and multi-use, so expect to see other hikers, mountain bikers, equestrians. There is also a bathroom and covered picnic table.
Bitter cherry bushes, fiddle neck, showy phlox, puccoon, prairie stars are some of the flowers you may see, as well as balsamroot and lupine. But all the gorgeous flowers come with a prices -- be sure to check for ticks!

places.name: Victoria Tract - Pilchuck Tree Farm
places.directions: Go north on I-5 to exit 215 (300th Street) and get off. Turn right and go about a mile to English Grade Road and turn left. Go about 2-3 miles to 316th and turn right and up the hill. At the top of the hill, turn left, through the Gla**chool gate and park at the lot provided about a quarter of a mile up the road on the left. If full, you may park just inside the gate to the left on the grassy area there. Hint: shadier on those hot days if you want to come back to a cool car. Trails eminate from all points. Will take some exploring to put your favorite loops together

activities.name: Victoria Tract - Pilchuck Tree Farm
activities.description: Located north of Arlington, WA. (I-5, exit 215). Nice mix of logging roads and single track. Trails were developed and are heavily used by Equestrians. It's a pretty good push to the top but the views are worth it. Lots of roads and trails to explore.

activities.name: Victoria Tract - Pilchuck Tree Farm
activities.description: Victoria Tract - Pilchuck Tree Farm features 35 miles of hiking trails near Arlington, WA.

places.name: Hospital Hill
places.directions: Starts off of NE Skyline Dr. Take Hwy 14 to E Oak St in Bingen, WA to E Jewett Blvd, to NE Skyline Dr.

activities.name: Hospital Hill
activities.description: Network of mostly singletrack trails with 2500+ feet of elevation gain, from floor of the Gorge to top of the ridge. Options include steep, tight switchbacks, long climbs in your granniest of all gears, great downhill runs, fantastic view from the top of the Gorge and Mt Hood. Sections also include quite a bit of exposure. Often have to cross fences, keep an eye out for hikers and other bikers coming back. For advanced riders only. Complete quess on the trail length.

activities.name: Hospital Hill
activities.description: Hospital Hill features 12 miles of hiking trails near White Salmon, WA.

places.name: Maryhill State Park
places.directions: Located 12 miles south of Goldendale, Wash. in Klickitat County.
places.description: Maryhill State Park is a 99-acre camping park with 4,700 feet of waterfront on the Columbia River in Klickitat County. The area is significant for its natural beauty, its access to the surrounding natural wonders and its cultural history. A full-scale model of Stonehenge stands near the park.

activities.name: Maryhill State Park
activities.description: Beautiful hiking area.

activities.name: Maryhill State Park
activities.description: Maryhill State Park is a 99-acre camping park with 4,700 feet of waterfront on the Columbia River in Klickitat County. The area is significant for its natural beauty, its access to the surrounding natural wonders and its cultural history. A full-scale model of Stonehenge stands near the park.

places.name: Narbeck Wetland Sanctuary Park
places.directions: 6900 Seaway Boulevard<br />Everett, WA
places.description: This 42.76 acre park  is accessible for passive recreational use with trails, interpretive signs, viewpoints, picnic tables, and restrooms. Narbeck offers two (2) walking trails, a small loop trail and a 1/2 mile interpretative trail around the perimeter, with educational signs and self guided tours.

activities.name: Narbeck Wetland Sanctuary Park
activities.description: This 42.76 acre park  is accessible for passive recreational use with trails, interpretive signs, viewpoints, picnic tables, and restrooms. Narbeck offers two (2) walking trails, a small loop trail and a 1/2 mile interpretative trail around the perimeter, with educational signs and self guided tours.

places.name: Gold Creek / Trail #830
places.directions: Located at the end of Whiskey Bend Rd. off FS 2909.

activities.name: Gold Creek / Trail #830
activities.description:
Conifer forest on steep mountain slopes in the Dungeness drainage. Nice view of Dungeness River near trailhead. The trail is heavily wooded with viewpoints.<br />
Pack and saddle stock, "street-legal" motorbike, and mountain bike users may want to make a long loop trip by traveling up the trail and returning on Forest Road #2870. Water is scarce. via fs.usda.gov

places.name: Stick Pin Trail #71
places.directions: Access #1-From Kettle Falls follow U.S. Highway 395 north 22 miles. Turn west on Boulder Creek Road 61 and follow for 2 miles. Turn left on South Boulder Road 6110 and travel 13 miles to junction of Albian Hill Road 2030. Turn right on road 2030 and follow for 0.7 miles to road 2030-910.  <br /><br />Access #2- From Kettle Falls follow U.S. Highway 395 to State route 20. Continue on State route 20 for 22 miles. Turn north on Albian Hill Road 2030 and travel 22.1 miles to road #2030-910.

activities.description: Stick Pin trail provides access to the Kettle Crest (North) National Recreation Trail #13. Good vistas reward traveler near trail's end. Horseback Riding.

places.name: Red Bluff Trail #553
places.directions: From the town of Metaline Falls, follow State Highway 31 north for 2.4 miles to the junction of Sullivan Lake Road (County Road 9345). Turn right (south) and follow the Sullivan Lake Road for 3.9 miles to the trailhead.

activities.name: Red Bluff Trail #553
activities.description:
Trail is densely wooded with moderate to steep grades. Connects with the Halliday Trail #522 and the North Fork Trail #507 for additional hiking. This area is closed to motorized use.<br />
<br />
Challenging ride. NOTE: Trail connects with the North Fork Trail #507. Bicycles are not allowed on portion of trail in Salmo-Priest Wilderness Area. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Clear Creek
places.directions: From Seattle, take I-5  north to the Arlington exit. Turn east on Highway 30 to the townof Darrington, then turn south on Mt. Loop Highway and continue 3 miles to Clear Creek Campground.

activities.name: Clear Creek
activities.description: Clear Creek Campground is located just off the Mountain Loop Highway in the stunning Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest.      Nestled in a towering canopy of fir trees, this campground offers plenty of open spaces, making it perfect for small groups and family excursions.      Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest sits on the west side of the Cascades in Washington, showcasing glacier-covered peaks, wide mountain meadows and old-growth forests, rich in history and outdoor opportunities.

places.name: The spot
places.directions: Swaford pond

activities.name: The spot
activities.description: Quiet away from people

places.name: Lena Lake Campground
places.directions: Travel US Highway 101 to FS Rd. #25 (hamma hamma rec.area) 14 miles north of HoodsportTurn west onto FS Rd. #25 and drive 8 miles to Lena Lake trailhead. Hike the trail (#810) for 3.2 miles to the campground on west shore of the lake.

activities.name: Lena Lake Campground
activities.description: This campground is only accessible by trail. Its a large 55 acre lake nestled among rugged peaks on the Hamma Hamma drainage. the campground is located at 1,800 ft so check on conditions befor heading up.

places.name: Greenwater
places.directions: SouthWest

activities.name: Greenwater
activities.description: On river

places.name: Lime Kiln Trailhead
places.directions: 22221 Waite - Mill Road, Granite Falls, WA
places.description: The trail was completed in 2007 by a group of volunteers living in and around Granite Falls and led by Steve Dean. Park staff and this group of volunteers scouted out new trails to circumvent some of the washout sections. Majority of the "abandoned" railroad is retained. The Park Department later installed a trailhead.

activities.name: Lime Kiln Trailhead
activities.description: A series of trail signs, mile markers and trail names are installed along the way. The major landmark is the Lime Kiln structure. Behind it is where the lime was mined. Along the trail, there is a series of squatters and rail activity remnants. The scenery and the landscape are spectacular.

places.name: Plymouth
places.directions: From Kennewick, Washington, take US-395 south for 23 miles to exit 131. Merge onto State Route 14 west and continue for 1.5 miles to Plymouth Road. Turn south and after 1.5 miles take a right on Christie Road. Turn left into the campground and follow signs to the day-use area.

activities.name: Plymouth
activities.description: Plymouth Park is located on a small island on Lake Umatilla on the Columbia River. The town of Plymouth, Washington, is less than a mile north.       Popular activities in the area include fishing, swimming, boating, water skiing and hunting.

places.name: Margaret McKenny
places.directions: From Olympia, travel south on Interstate 5 to the Littlerock exit, exit 95.  Follow this road for about 8 miles to the town of Littlerock.  This road now turns into 128th Ave.  Keep going straight on this road for .5 miles to the Waddle Creek Road and take a right.  Follow Waddle Creek Road for about 1.5 miles to the campground entrance on your left.

activities.name: Margaret McKenny
activities.description: This is a large campground with a stream nearby. There is a campground host and  hiking and horseback riding trails nearby.  About .5 miles or so before you reach this site, there is a road to the left marked ""Mima Mounds Natural Area"". It's only about a mile to the site, and well worth the journey. There is an interpretive display and about 1900 feet of handicap access barrier-free paved trail through the mysteriously mounded prairie.I found this site in the book ""Rays Guides, free campgrounds in Washington""

places.name: Manastash Lake Trail #1350
places.directions: TBD

activities.name: Manastash Lake Trail #1350
activities.description: Out and back to Lake Manastash.

places.name: Silvia Ridge Loop
places.directions: From the small town of Montesano, take third street up the hill from Pioneer into Lake Silvia State Park. Proceed into the park over the bridge. Ride West along the lake, cross over the damn and follow Lower Silvia Creek Trail down the valley, across Silvia Creek and back towards the lake. There are three ways up Hamby Hill, I prefer taking the third entrance you come to on the uphill side from the main trail. Take one to extend this loop with much more single track or proceed back to the lake on main trail. At the top of Hamby hill follow the logging spurs (A-1400) out to the main logging road (the Montesano A-line). Head right down the hill and at the crest of the next hill keep a close lookout for the start of Silvia Ridge trail in deep forest. Follow this perfect deep woods single track along the ridge (crossing two small spurs) until it opens out onto a wide intersection. The Silvia Ridge trail continues on down the hill but that section has just been destroyed (Winter 03) by a commercial thinning operation (this is a multi-use City of Montesano managed forest). At this intersection follow the major spur (b-300) to the right past a locked gate through the forest until you crest a hill opening into a very large clearcut. Stay to the right (left is another out, but a poor choice) down the hill across the clearcut and back to another crest as you near the lower timber line. The next single track section called Pine Winder (Pine something, no sign) begins on the left from that crest and winds down and across the ridge utill it dumps you just inside the treeline on to the Silvia Creek trail. Hang a left and return to the Lake from which you began.

activities.name: Sylvia Ridge Loop
activities.description: This loop takes just about an hour and can be ridden either way, both directions will include some great downhill or push a bike sections (Hamby Hill and Pine Winder). The trails are somewhat documented on maps that may be available from the City of Montesanon Forestry Department (Pine Winder excluded). The Lake Silvia area also includes a great loop of the Silvia East Fork trail, Cougar Ridge and back either the West Fork trail (old RR spur following the creek--can be mud bog from ATV use) or back on the X-line to the A-line dumping you out in the middle of the Silvia Ridge trail. Have fun, buy a State of Washington season parking pass (it is revenue enhancement time in our state managed resources) and I hope you enjoy this as much as I do.

activities.name: Silvia Ridge Loop
activities.description: Silvia Ridge Loop features 5 miles of hiking trails near Montesano, WA.

places.name: Wynoochee Lake Shore / Trail #878
places.directions: From Olympia, WA travel north on Highway 101 towards Shelton, WA for about 19 miles. Take the exit towards Matlock and travel approximately 15 miles on Dayton-Matlock Road. From Matlock, continue straight at the junction onto the Matlock-Deckerville Road, which turns into the Boundary Road. Drive 8.8 miles, make a right turn onto Cougar-Smith Road and drive about 5.5 miles to Forest Service Road #22. <br /><br />Turn right on Forest Service Road #22 and drive 15 miles on Forest Service Road #22 to a major intersection and take Forest Service Road 2270 on the east side of Wynoochee Lake towards Wynoochee Falls.

activities.name: Wynoochee Lake Shore / Trail #878
activities.description:
Small streams and waterfalls, Wynoochee River, Wynoochee Lake, old-growth and second growth forests are all part of the experience along this 16 mile loop trail.<br />
The 16-mile Wynoochee Lake Shore Trail follows 6 miles along the lakeshore, extends another 2 miles upriver to a bridge over the Wynoochee River, then returns to the Coho campground in 8 miles on the opposite side of the river/lake. via fs.usda.gov

places.name: Rock Mountain Trail #1587
places.directions: The trail begins at the Rock Mountain Trailhead located on the North side of Highway 2 near milepost 73. The trail ends at the Nason Ridge Trail #1583.

activities.name: Rock Mountain Trail #1587
activities.description: This very steep, dry, and scenic trail access the old Rock Mountain lookout site and Rock Lake. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Soaring Eagle
places.directions: From 228th in Sammamish turn East on SE 8th Street and follow it east.  It turns North and becomes 244th Ave SE.  Turn right (East) on Main Street and follow this to the end and into the park parking lot.

activities.name: Soaring Eagle Regional Park
activities.description:
Single track with a wide trail through the middle.<br />
Network of single track trails with great maps.<br />
<br />
Fairly easy but a great place for beginners to learn mountain biking and for others to have a quick fun ride.

places.name: Shannon Creek
places.directions: From Seattle, take I-5 north to Mt. Vernon. Take Exit 230 on StateHighway 20 and go past Sedro-Woolley. Take Baker Lake Road to Baker Lake.

activities.name: Shannon Creek
activities.description: Shannon Creek Campground is nestled along the western shore of Baker Lake in the Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest on the west side of the Cascades. The area is one of the most spectacular in the country, showcasing glacier-covered peaks, broad mountain meadows and old-growth forests. An abundance of recreational activities awaits.

places.name: Galbraith Mtn
places.directions: I-5 to Bellingham. East on lakeway Drive to Whatcom Falls park.

activities.name: Galbraith Mtn
activities.description: Galbraith Mt. is located In Bellingham, WA. between Lakeway Dr. to the north, Yew St. to the west and Samish Dr. on the south. The most distinguishing feature on the mountain is a tall stand of trees at the top that was left untouched after the most recent logging.  The trails up at the top can be accessed either from Whatcom Falls park on the north or Galbraith Lane on the south side. This area is full of single track, double track and dirt roads. It would take many trips to explore them all. Elevation gain is about 800'. An excellent resource is Galbraithmtn.com which has some very good maps, photos and route descriptions.

activities.name: Galbraith Mtn
activities.description: Galbraith Mtn features 20 miles of hiking trails near Bellingham, WA.

places.name: Sleepy Hollow Trail
places.directions: Access via FS 28 near Gold Creek.

activities.name: Sleepy Hollow Trail
activities.description: Singletrack trail that connects the Mt. Zion Trail with the Gold Creek trail.

places.name: Grayland Beach State Park
places.directions: West from Aberdeen Washington on state route 105. North from South Bend on state route 105

activities.name: Grayland Beach State Park
activities.description: State park campground nestled right on the beach. Some campsites are located in a treed area, but some are located along the beach.

places.name: Schmitz Preserve Park
places.directions: 5551 SW Admiral Way, 98116
places.description: Schmitz Preserve Park in West Seattle is a great place to head out for a walk in the park. Once a place for a logger's heyday, this park is now a quiet and untouched place that give peace of mind to visitors. This is a truly great place to get away from things for a bit and take a hike!

activities.name: Schmitz Preserve Park
activities.description: Schmitz Preserve Park in West Seattle is a great place to head out for a walk in the park. Once a place for a logger's heyday, this park is now a quiet and untouched place that give peace of mind to visitors. This is a truly great place to get away from things for a bit and take a hike!

places.name: Coffeepot Lake
places.directions: Located west of Harrington, in Lincoln County Washington. From Highway 28, turn west onto Coffeepot Road and travel about 12 miles to the gravel entrance on the left. Plan for a drive of about 1 Â½ hours from Spokane.
places.description: Impressive basalt cliffs frame this eastern Washington lake. More than 900 acres bordering the lake are managed for wildlife habitat, as well as for recreational opportunities including boating, fishing*, hiking, horseback riding, camping, and picnicking (* Check Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife for Season and Special Fishing Gear Rules). Waterfowl are protected by a game reserve on public lands around Coffeepot Lake. Hunting and use of hunting dogs are prohibited within the game reserve.

More than 900 acres bordering the lake are managed for wildlife habitat, as well as for recreational opportunities including boating, fishing*, hiking, horseback riding, camping, and picnicking (* Check Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife for Season and Special Fishing Gear Rules).
