places.directions: TBD

activities.name: Quartz Creek Trail #949
activities.description: Begins at forest road 1903 and ends at trail 688  Most Difficult. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Mount Pilchuck State Park
places.directions: Take I-5 to Snohomish-Wenatchee exit 194. Drive east on Highway 2 for six miles and then north on Highway 9, following signs to Granite Falls. Continue east on the Mountain Loop Highway 11 miles to Verlot.
places.description: Mount Pilchuck State Park is a 1,893-acre day-use park that features mountainous alpine terrain with diverse scenic and recreation attractions.  The main recreational attraction of the park is the three-mile trail to the summit and the old fire lookout. The trail begins at 3100 feet above sea level and winds through an old growth forest to alpine heather and large rocks at the summit of Mount Pilchuck (5324 feet above sea level). The hike is strenuous and in the summer can be very crowded. At the top is an incredible panoramic view of the Cascades, Olympics and Puget Sound. The trail is usually covered with snow until midsummer.

activities.name: Mount Pilchuck State Park
activities.description: The park's most notable feature is a fire lookout building that sits atop the mountain. The fire lookout is on the National Historic Building register and has five interpretive plaques which identify the mountains seen from the building. There also are displays about the history of the lookout.

places.name: Potholes Reservoir
places.directions: Site is located 15 miles south of Moses Lake off State Road 262.  To visit south shore of reservoir, use State Highway 17 south from Moses Lake for 10 miles, west of State Hwy 262.  For north shore, leave I-90 at Exit 169 (Hiawatha) west of Moses Lake, S to frontage road.  East 2.6 miles.  Before large towers, take dirt road to right to dike

activities.name: Potholes Reservoir
activities.description: The Potholes Reservoir is part of the Columbia Basin Project and formed by OSullivan Dam. Potholes refers to the many glacial depressions in ancient sand dunes here. These potholes and small islands make this area one of the best in Washington for birding. The best birding is from March through October: Sandhill cranes and waterfowl in late February, raptors in April, Sage Thrasher, Lark Sparrow, Burrowing and Long-eared Owls and shorebirds in May. With the August reservoir drawdown, the exposed mudflats attract shorebirds such as a variety of sandpipers, stilts, plovers and curlews.Area is open year-round. Other developed campsites are available at Mardon Resort; (509)346-2651. Access to the reservoir is adequate except west side is limited. Fish species include yellow perch, crappie, largemouth bass, rainbow trout, and walleye. Fishing is year-round. Wildlife area information. .

places.name: Burke-Gilman Trail
places.directions: Access Points: Gasworks Park, Matthews Beach Park, Log Boom Park.
places.description: The Burke-Gilman Trail runs more than 18 miles from Shilshole Bay in the City of Seattle to the City of Bothell where it intersects the Sammamish River Trail. Part of the "Locks to Lakes Corridor," the BGT is a paved, off-road facility over its entire length with the exception of an on-road segment in Ballard. The trail crosses Ballard, Fremont, Wallingford, the University District and View Ridge within the City of Seattle, as well as the cities of Lake Forest Park, Kenmore and Bothell. The trail is managed by Seattle within the city limits south of Northeast 145th Street and by King County outside Seattle.

activities.name: Burke-Gilman Trail
activities.description: The trail follows a historic railroad route near the Lake Washington Ship Canal and north along Lake Washington to the Sammamish River. Along the way it passes the Hiram Chittenden Locks, Fremont Canal Park, Gas Works Park, University of Washington, Magnuson Park, Log Boom Park in Kenmore, Wayne Golf Course in Bothell and Blyth Park in Bothell. King County's best-known regional trail, the BGT is highly popular with cyclists, joggers, skaters and strollers. It is also an important nonmotorized route for weekday bicycle commuters between Seattle and the Eastside. The trail provides great access and views of the Ship Canal, Lake Union, Seattle neighborhoods, suburban cities, Lake Washington, and points east via other regional trails.

places.name: Cattle Point
places.directions: Access to the site is along a paved San Juan County public road Cattle Point road. Parking is limited. Additional parking is available nearby at the WA DNR, Cattle Point Interpretive Center. Currently a Washington State Discovery Pass is required to park at the DNR site.
places.description: Cattle Point offers sweeping vistas of rugged, sandy bluffs, San Juan Island's south shores and the Strait of Juan De Fuca. The stunning backdrop of nearby islands, the Olympic Mountains, and the Salish Sea make the Cattle Point Lighthouse one of the most photographed lighthouses in Washington State. Recreational activities include hiking, picnicking, fishing, sea kayaking, watching wildlife, or viewing wildflowers. Cattle Point is available for day-use only. The site can be somewhat crowded during the peak use of the summer visitors can enjoy a more isolated experience during the shoulder seasons. Parking is limited.

activities.name: Cattle Point
activities.description: Excellent hiking area.

places.name: Mccollum Park
places.directions: From I-5 southbound take exit 186, turn left onto 128th St SW / WA-96 for 1/4 mile, park entrance is on your right.  From I-5 northbound take exit 186, turn right onto 128th St SW / WA-96 for 1/4 mile, park entrance is on your right.

activities.name: Mccollum Park
activities.description: McCollum Pioneer Park is a 78 acre family-oriented park, with a rich combination of natural habitats that supports a wide variety of both active and passive recreation opportunities.  Its presence serves as a living memorial to the original pioneers who settled this area.  Our heated outdoor (junior Olympic size) pool offers swim lessons during the summer months and open swim each afternoon.  Take a morning stroll on our nature trails or bring your family and friends out for a picnic.  Conveniently located 1/4 mile from I-5.

places.name: Pearrygin Lake State Park
places.directions: Located four miles northeast of Winthrop, Wash., in north central Washington in Okanogan County.
places.description: Pearrygin Lake State Park is a camping park with more than 1,200 acres in the Methow Valley of north central Washington. The park features expansive green lawns leading to 11,000 feet of waterfront on Pearrygin Lake. The lake offers swimming, fishing and boating. Old willows and ash provide shade on hot summer days. Hikers can also walk the Rex Derr trail, a 3.1-mile loop through the east campground and along the shrub steppe hillside above Pearrygin Lake.

activities.name: Pearrygin Lake State Park
activities.description: The park features the 3.1-mile Rex Derr trail, a multi-seasonal trail that begins at the east boat launch, traverses a hillside up through the shrub-steppe environment, skirts the old Graves Homestead and winds its way back through the east campground.

activities.name: Pearrygin Lake State Park
activities.description: Pearrygin Lake State Park is a camping park with more than 1,200 acres in the Methow Valley of north central Washington. The park features expansive green lawns leading to 11,000 feet of waterfront on Pearrygin Lake. The lake offers swimming, fishing and boating. Old willows and ash provide shade on hot summer days. Hikers can also walk the Rex Derr trail, a 3.1-mile loop through the east campground and along the shrub steppe hillside above Pearrygin Lake.

places.name: Crescent Bar Resort
places.directions: None

activities.name: Crescent Bar Resort
activities.description: If rest and relaxation are your idea of a perfect vacation, this preserve may be what your dreams are made of. More than 300 days of sunshine per year provide the opportunity to enjoy spectacular vistas of the Columbia River and the mountains that surround this location.

places.name: Willows
places.directions: From Naches, Washington, take Route 12 west 4.4 miles to the intersection with State Route 410. Turn left at the intersection, staying on Route 12. Travel 15 miles to campground on the left.

activities.name: Willows
activities.description: Willows Campground sits on the eastern slopes of the Cascade Mountains at the southern end of the Okanogan-Wenatchee National Forest, offering visitors some of the most stunning scenery in Washington and easy access to an abundance of recreational   activities.

places.name: Griffin Creek
places.directions: Coming from Seattle: go east on I-90 to the Preston-Fall City exit. Turn left, over the freeway and then right, towards Fall City. Once in town, turn right, over the bridge on 202 and then a left, heading north on 203. Take that road about 5-6 miles to NE 11th and turn right. There will also be a Camp Don Bosco sign there. When the paved road veers left, stay straight onto the dirt road; parking area is up the dirt road on the left before the Snoqualmie Valley trail.

activities.name: Griffin Creek
activities.description: Mixture of sevice roads and single track running through a tree farm. fairly flat area with minor elevation gain. Good drainage in wet weather. Good trails for the novice riders.

places.name: Desert Wildlife Rec. Area
places.directions: South from Ephrata on State Highway 283.

activities.name: Desert Wildlife Rec. Area
activities.description: This area includes Winchester Reservoir, Winchester Wasteway, Frenchman Hills Wasteway, and numerous small ponds and marshes.  Fishing is year-round for yellow perch, crappie, largemouth bass, smallmouth bass, and rainbow trout.  Access is limited in some areas.  Boat motors are prohibited seasonally on Winchester Wasteway.  Some sites have restrooms and boat ramps.

places.name: Camano Is. State Park
places.directions: Enter the state park and keep left until you find a trail head sign and parking.

activities.name: Camano Is. State Park
activities.description: Numerous short trails thorough out the park ranging from .7-3 Miles. all are single track and some have some brutal climbs!

places.name: Ape Canyon#234, Abraham#216d, Smith Creek#225 Trails
places.directions: From I5 take Exit #21 in Woodland, WA. Head East on Lewis River Rd/WA503 about 23 miles where the road becomes FR90. Continue threw Cougar until you reach the Swift Reservoir. Turn left going onto Nat for Dev Rd 83 contining about 17 to 18 miles to the Ape Canyon trailhead with a small paved parking area on the left.

activities.name: Ape Canyon#234, Abraham#216d, Smith Creek#225 Trails
activities.description: This trail has it all. You have to see it to believe it. From Steep tight single track to riding on the surface of the moon. There is a 1.5 mile section of dirt/paved road to link the Abraham#216D Trail to the Smith Creek#225 trial.

places.name: Clarks Creek Park
places.directions: From Clarks Creek Park Parking<br /><br />Follow the fire road grade up from the tennis courts past the small shack. <br /><br />(If you parked in the south parking lot the shack will be right in front of <br /><br />you). This doubletrack turns to singletrack with a steep grade up the hill. At <br /><br />the top are a few loops to ride. There are a couple of mini bridges that drop <br /><br />to flat up by the school.<br /><br /><br /><br />From Fruitland Elementary<br /><br />Park in the parking lot. Head behind the school. The forest on the backside <br /><br />of the playfields has the trails. If you go between the portables and enter <br /><br />the forest you'll find the southern loop right through the trees.

activities.name: Clarks Creek Park
activities.description:
Two main loops that are at the top. Both loops are fairly easy with just a <br />
couple difficult inclines and a couple obstacles.

activities.name: Clarks Creek Park
activities.description: Clarks Creek Park is a 6 mile hiking trail in Puyallup, Washington.

places.name: Leavenworth
places.directions: None

activities.name: Leavenworth
activities.description: Nestled in the eastern foothills of the Cascade Mountains, the alpine setting of the Leavenworth preserve is refreshing. Sunny summers provide perfect conditions for hiking, fishing, river rafting or sunbathing on the shores of beautiful Lake Wenatchee. During the winter months, cross-country skiing, snowmobiling and snowshoeing are accessible from the preserve. The preserve is also located just 30 miles from the Steven&amp;#39;s Pass Ski Resort and 55 miles from Mission Ridge Ski area. No matter what the season, the nearby village of Leavenworth is a real treat with its Bavarian architecture, unique German restaurants, specialty shops and art galleries.

places.name: Cherry Valley
places.directions: I-405 to SR 522. Take the Woodinville - Duvall exit. Head East into the town of Duvall. Turn left, heading North, and then an immediate(in town)right up on to NE Cherry Valley Road. Take this to Cherry Gardens Community Club at the junction of Mountain view Road and where NE Cherry valley turns into Kelly Road. Turn hard left, on to Mountain View and park there on the side of the road. Either go up the dirt road 100 feet ahead, to the right and take the trail about 200 yards up from there, or, just go in behind the silver gate across from Cherry Gardens. Please do not park in Club lot. Irresponsible biker and equestrian usage have closed it for us and no good will come from parking there.

activities.name: Cherry Valley
activities.description: Nice variety of single & double track and lots of service roads.

activities.name: Cherry Valley
activities.description: Cherry Valley features 15 miles of hiking trails near Duval, WA.

places.name: Newhalem Campground
places.directions: To reach the North Cascades, drive State Route 20, the North Cascades Highway, from Burlington on the west or Twisp on the east. Newhalem Campground is located at Mile Marker 120 on State Route 20.

activities.name: Newhalem Campground
activities.description: Newhalem Campground is a comfortable facility close to the town of Newhalem, Washington and the Skagit River. It is surrounded by forests that that can be explored through the area&amp;#39;s many hiking trails. The campground has individual and family campsites, as well as two group sites that are popular among school and volunteer groups. It is private and secluded, yet the town, a visitor center and other amenities are only a short walk away.

places.name: Griffiths-Priday State Park
places.directions: Located 21 miles northwest of Hoquiam, Wash., on the coast of the Pacific Ocean in Grays Harbor County.
places.description: Griffiths-Priday Ocean State Park is a 364-acre marine park with 8,316 feet of saltwater shoreline on the Pacific Ocean and 9,950 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Copalis River. The park extends from the beach through low dunes to the river, then north to the river's mouth. The Copalis Spit natural area, a designated wildlife refuge, is also part of the park.

places.name: Sullivan Lake
places.directions: 95 miles north of Spokane, Washington, take Hwy 31 north through Metaline Falls.  About 1 mile north of Metaline Falls turn onto Sullivan Lake (County Road 9345).  Travel 6.5 miles to junction with Forest Road 22. Turn on FR 22 and follow .2 miles to the campground.

activities.name: Sullivan Lake
activities.description: East Sullivan Campground is perched along the north shore of Sullivan Lake near the town of Metaline Falls, Washington. The campground provides a unique environment where campers can enjoy swimming, fishing, sailing and whitewater paddling.     A small grassy airstrip adjacent to the campground allows campers to fly in via charter plane or bring their own small aircraft.

places.name: Armstrong tract
places.directions: From I-5 take exit 212 for WA-532. Turn east and travel 4.1 miles. WA-532 turns into Granview Rd at the junction of Hwy 9. Continue for 1.0 miles and turn right onto 272nd street NE. After about 1/10th of a mile turn right into the trailhead/staging areas.

activities.name: Armstrong tract
activities.description: This trail system is run and maintained primarily by equestrian group please use caution and respect around horses, they have the right of way. The Pilchuck Tree Farm is a huge chunk of private land north of Arlington and near the small community of Bryant that is used for logging. The company/land owners have allowed trails and public recreation on their land for over 20 years. Of course patches of trail are going to go away from time to time as various segments gets logged over the years. Despite the obvious bummage of this, the up side is the place is ever changing. There are several tracts to the tree farm; Victoria, Armstrong and the Pilchuck tracts. The Pilchuck and the Victoria tracts are closed during the winter (November 1st - April 30th) due to the wet conditions.

places.name: Pass Lake Trail
places.directions: : From Interstate 5 in Skagit County, take Exit 230 (Anacortes/Burlington) and head west on Highway 20. After 12 miles, cross the bridge to Fidalgo Island, and watch for signs to turn left to Whidbey Island. After the turn, go six miles, and just after going by Pass Lake on the right, turn right on Rosario Road, then immediately turn right into the parking lot.

activities.name: Pass Lake Trail
activities.description: Pass Lake trail  a great trail to get back into the swing of things after a wet winter, not to long and not to short. There are a few tough spots but its a pretty easy trail over all.

places.name: Tambark Creek Park
places.directions: From SR-527 (Bothell-Everett Hwy) head east on 180th St SE.  To reach the west entrance, turn left (north) onto 35th St SE and proceed approximately 1/10th of a mile (park is on the right).  To reach the east entrance, continue heading east on 180th and take a left onto Sunset Rd.  From Sunset turn left onto 176th St SE and follow to the end of the road.
places.description: Tambark Park is a 40-acre blend of open fields, woodlands, and wetlands, with features that include restrooms, sports field, picnic shelters, and off-leash area.

activities.name: Tambark Creek Park
activities.description: Tambark Park is a 40-acre blend of open fields, woodlands, and wetlands, with features that include restrooms, sports field, picnic shelters, and off-leash area.

places.name: Green Mountain Trail
places.directions: From Bremerton ferry terminal follow Washington St north until you hit 11th St. Head West on 11th until you hit Kitsap Way take a right on Kitsap way follow Kitsap way until you get to Northlake way. Take a left on Northlake way and stay to the right at first Y. Turn left at the second Y. Follow road up the hill towards Seabeck. Turn Left at union Rd go past Wildcat Lake grocery store and Look for the Wild Cat Lake trailhead on your left about a mile and a half past the store.

activities.name: Green Mountain Trail
activities.description: <BR>The first six miles are mostly up hill, so be prepared for a little huffin n puffin. The view from the top on a clear day and the great downhill is the reward for the climb up, Have Fun!

activities.name: Green Mountain Trail
activities.description: Green Mountain Trail features 12 miles of hiking trails near Bremerton, WA.

places.name: Middle Fork Teanaway Trail #1393
places.directions: TBD

activities.name: Middle Fork Teanaway Trail #1393
activities.description: The Middle Fork Teanaway Trail begins at Forest Service Road 4305-113 and ends at Trail #1393.1. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: North Fork Entiat River Trail #1437
places.directions: TBD

activities.name: North Fork Entiat River Trail #1437
activities.description: The North Fork Entiat River Trail begins at Forest Service Road 5606 and ends at Trail #1433. Lower areas of the trail burned in the Pyramid Fire 2012 use caution when traveling through areas of burned trees and snags. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Syncline
places.directions: 3 miles east of Bingen Washington Take hwy 14, (across the river from Hood River Oregon). Park at the base of Courtney road. Ride east for 1/3 mile, around the base of the syncline cliffs and start climbing up the many zig zag trails that climb the slope on the left

places.name: Rasar State Park
places.directions: Located along the north shore of the Skagit River, approximately 19 miles east of Burlington, Wash. in Skagit County.
places.description: Rasar State Park is a 169-acre camping park with 4,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Skagit River. Wildlife observation opportunities, especially for eagle watching, are excellent, particularly in early fall and early winter.

activities.name: Rasar State Park
activities.description: 1 miles ADA hiking trails.

activities.name: Rasar State Park
activities.description: Rasar State Park is a 169-acre camping park with 4,000 feet of freshwater shoreline on the Skagit River. Wildlife observation opportunities, especially for eagle watching, are excellent, particularly in early fall and early winter.

places.name: Lower Chiwawa ORV Trail #1548
places.directions: The trail begins at Deep Creek at the junction of Forest Roads #6100 and #6101, but the main trailhead is located across from the Goose Creek Campground on Forest Road #6100.  The trail ends at the junction of the Minnow Ridge ORV Trail #1524 and the Chikamin Creek ORV Trail #1534.

activities.name: Lower Chiwawa ORV Trail #1548
activities.description: This trail goes along hills above the Chiwawa Valley Road #6200. The trail is maintained primarily for motorcycles and mountain bikes and is rated as an easy ride. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Silver Springs
places.directions: From Enumclaw, Washington, drive approximately 33 miles southeast on State Highway 410 toward Mount Rainier National Park.

activities.name: Silver Springs
activities.description: Silver Springs Campground is situated on the banks of the scenic White River in Mt. Baker-Snoqualmie National Forest, just outside Mt. Rainier National Park&amp;#39;s North Arch entrance. Silver Springs offers visitors stunning scenery and access to a multitude of recreational activities.

places.name: Cranberry - Heart Lake, Anacortes Acfl
places.directions: A well planned set of mostly singletrack trails cut through thick forests <br /><br />around a few lakes and over several ridges. There are a couple of old FS <br /><br />roads at the south end of this area that link several trails together. Out of <br /><br />the three ACFL areaâs this one has the most beginner/intermediate <br /><br />riding. Access to the Heart Lake area can be found at the SE corner off of FS <br /><br />road 10. There are maps located at a few of the main trailheads but picking <br /><br />up a map at the LBS is recommended. All trails are well signed at <br /><br />intersections, numbered and although may not be in order do make sense <br /><br />after you have ridden here a bit. There are a few trails that are designated <br /><br />for hikers only, predominantly around the immediate lake shores and some <br /><br />steep ridges.

places.name: Bridgeport State Park
places.directions: Located three miles northeast of Bridgeport, Wash., in the north central area of the state in Okanogan County.
places.description: Bridgeport State Park is a 748-acre camping park with 7,500 feet of freshwater shoreline on Rufus Woods Lake. Set directly behind Chief Joseph Dam, this lake is actually a segment of the Columbia River. The park provides 18 acres of lawn and some shade in the midst of a desert terrain. "Haystacks," unusual volcanic formations resembling their name, are the park's most striking feature.

activities.name: Bridgeport State Park
activities.description: Bridgeport State Park is a 748-acre camping park with 7,500 feet of freshwater shoreline on Rufus Woods Lake. Set directly behind Chief Joseph Dam, this lake is actually a segment of the Columbia River. The park provides 18 acres of lawn and some shade in the midst of a desert terrain. "Haystacks," unusual volcanic formations resembling their name, are the park's most striking feature.

activities.name: Bridgeport State Park
activities.description: Bridgeport State Park is a 748-acre camping park with 7,500 feet of freshwater shoreline on Rufus Woods Lake. Set directly behind Chief Joseph Dam, this lake is actually a segment of the Columbia River. The park provides 18 acres of lawn and some shade in the midst of a desert terrain. "Haystacks," unusual volcanic formations resembling their name, are the park's most striking feature.

places.name: Cutthroat Trail
places.directions: From Winthrop drive State Route 20 west about 26 miles (or 1.5 miles west of Lone Fir Campground). Turn right on Forest Service Road 400 and follow for 1 mile to the trailhead.

activities.name: Cutthroat Trail
activities.description: Open to mountain bikes up to junction with Pacific Crest Trail. No bikes allowed on Pacific Crest Trail. source: fs.usda.gov

places.name: Snoqualmie Ridge Neighborhood Trails
places.directions: Can be accessed from many points on Snoqualmie Ridge, and from the Preston Snoqualmie rail trail east of Lake Alice road.

activities.name: Snoqualmie Ridge Neighborhood Trails
activities.description: The trail system consists of wide, soft surface (sometimes bark covered), trails through the neighborhood.  Not destination worthy singletrack by any mean, but better than nothing for a quick ride after work.  Keeping speed under control is critical with the kids, hikers, dog walkers, runners, etc. on the trail.  Also beware of the local wildlife, including bears, coyotes, and the rare cougar sighting.

places.name: Noble Knob
places.directions: To come

places.name: Hog Canyon Lake
places.directions: Fishtrap is about a 30-mile drive southwest from Spokane, Washington. From Interstate 90, take Exit 254, turn left and head south on the Old State Hwy. From the Old State Hwy. to get to Hog Canyon Lake turn left onto Peterson Road and travel 1/2 mile to the access road entrance. The lake is approximately another 2 miles down the BLM access road.
places.description: The site is located within the BLM Fishtrap area and is open year-round. Recreation opportunities include boating, winter-only trout fishing, hiking, and horseback riding. Horseback riding typically starts from the Farmer's Landing parking lot along the access road south of the BLM ranch house (see site map). The entire water surface area of the lake is open for public use, but portions of the shoreline are privately owned. Refer to the map for shoreline private land boundaries and BLM public lands boundaries. The boat launch and all on-water recreation activities are administered by Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW). A WDFW permit is required to park in the parking lot. Please refer to Washington fishing and hunting regulations. No additional fees are charged by BLM. There are several non-motorized use trails at the site including the 1.3-mile Hog Lake Loop Trail which starts at the small BLM parking lot mid-way down the Hog Canyon Lake access road. Although slightly set back from the lake, the trail parallels the lake's west side, with easy off-trail access to overlooks of the lake.

activities.name: Hog Canyon Lake
activities.description: The site is located within the BLM Fishtrap area and is open year-round. Recreation opportunities include boating, winter-only trout fishing, hiking, and horseback riding. Horseback riding typically starts from the Farmer's Landing parking lot along the access road south of the BLM ranch house (see site map). The entire water surface area of the lake is open for public use, but portions of the shoreline are privately owned. Refer to the map for shoreline private land boundaries and BLM public lands boundaries. The boat launch and all on-water recreation activities are administered by Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife (WDFW). A WDFW permit is required to park in the parking lot. Please refer to Washington fishing and hunting regulations. No additional fees are charged by BLM. There are several non-motorized use trails at the site including the 1.3-mile Hog Lake Loop Trail which starts at the small BLM parking lot mid-way down the Hog Canyon Lake access road. Although slightly set back from the lake, the trail parallels the lake's west side, with easy off-trail access to overlooks of the lake.
